dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, uh, you know, with everything going on in 2020 – the pandemic, months of protests, a really contested election – Satya Nadella from Microsoft said something pretty bold.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, uh, you know, with everything going on in twenty twenty - the pandemic, months of protests, a really contested election - Satya Nadella from Microsoft said something pretty bold.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he did! He basically called for a "referendum on capitalism," right? Like, talking about reimagining it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he did! He basically called for a referendum on capitalism, right? Like, talking about reimagining it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its fair, in today in 2020, in the midst of this pandemic, to essentially have a referendum on capitalism, Satya Nadella, Microsofts CEO, said Wednesday during the Forbes JUST 100 virtual summit.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? Which, I mean, is a huge statement coming from the CEO of, like, the world's second-largest public company. What was his core point there, do you think?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Which, I mean, is a huge statement coming from the C E O of, like, the world's second-largest public company. What was his core point there, do you think?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Amid a global pandemic, months-long protests over racial inequality and a bitterly contested election, the CEO of the worlds second largest public company says now is the time for America to reimagine capitalism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, he said companies shouldn't just be measured by, um, their *internal* profits. He wants them to be judged by the jobs and revenue they create *outside* the company, their broader economic impact.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, he said companies shouldn't just be measured by, um, their internal profits. He wants them to be judged by the jobs and revenue they create outside the company, their broader economic impact.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In short, Nadella said, companies like Microsoft should be measured by the number of jobs and revenue created outside of the company and the economic impact they have on the markets where they operate, as opposed to surpluses generated within a company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, kind of shifting the focus from just shareholder value to something bigger. This sounds a lot like what they call "stakeholder capitalism," doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, kind of shifting the focus from just shareholder value to something bigger. This sounds a lot like what they call stakeholder capitalism, doesn't it?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nadellas comments, which he says were inspired by a book published last year by Oxford management studies professor Colin Mayer, follow ongoing calls for business leaders to commit to steering their corporations toward so-called stakeholder capitalism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. He even mentioned being inspired by a book on it. And, you know, it follows the World Economic Forum, Davos, the Business Roundtable – all those CEOs, like Bezos and Dimon, who signed on to promoting an economy that serves all Americans.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. He even mentioned being inspired by a book on it. And, you know, it follows the World Economic Forum, Davos, the Business Roundtable - all those C E Os, like Bezos and Dimon, who signed on to promoting an economy that serves all Americans.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nadellas comments, which he says were inspired by a book published last year by Oxford management studies professor Colin Mayer... Earlier this year, the World Economic Forum at Davos used the phrase as the theme for its annual event, a move that came after nearly 200 CEOs of large corporations including Amazon's Jeff Bezos and JPMorgan Chase's Jamie Dimon signed new guidelines by the Business Roundtable that specified the role of a corporation was to promote an economy that serves all Americans.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, though there's been some skepticism about how committed those companies actually are, uh, to that idea. Like, is it just talk?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, though there's been some skepticism about how committed those companies actually are, uh, to that idea. Like, is it just talk?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though a recent report cast doubt on just how committed these companies are to stakeholder capitalism, Nadella pointed to Microsofts pledge to become carbon neutral by 2030, and highlighted a push by LinkedIn to address racial inequality as initiatives supported by shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's fair. But Nadella did point to Microsoft's own actions, right? Like, their pledge to be carbon neutral by 2030, and LinkedIn's efforts on racial inequality. So, they're trying to walk the talk, at least in some areas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's fair. But Nadella did point to Microsoft's own actions, right? Like, their pledge to be carbon neutral by twenty thirty, and LinkedIn's efforts on racial inequality. So, they're trying to walk the talk, at least in some areas.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Though a recent report cast doubt on just how committed these companies are to stakeholder capitalism, Nadella pointed to Microsofts pledge to become carbon neutral by 2030, and highlighted a push by LinkedIn to address racial inequality as initiatives supported by shareholders.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And, you know, under Nadella, Microsoft has really, uh, seen explosive growth, especially with their cloud services. So he's not exactly hurting shareholder value while saying these things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And, you know, under Nadella, Microsoft has really, uh, seen explosive growth, especially with their cloud services. So he's not exactly hurting shareholder value while saying these things.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since Nadella took over as Microsoft CEO in 2013, the company has experienced explosive growth, in large part thanks to a booming cloud services business a sector that has only recorded surging demand during the pandemic as the global workforce was forced to work from home.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all. And it wasn't just about reimagining capitalism, either. He also touched on the federal election, which is a huge deal right now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all. And it wasn't just about reimagining capitalism, either. He also touched on the federal election, which is a huge deal right now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Beyond the pandemic and racial justice issues, Nadella also discussed the upcoming federal election, which has been overshadowed by President Donald Trumps assertions he may not accept its outcome.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, that's right! He emphasized how much Microsoft relies on a strong democracy, especially as an American tech company.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, that's right! He emphasized how much Microsoft relies on a strong democracy, especially as an American tech company.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Nadella emphasized Microsofts reliance on a strong democracy and the need to maintain its institutions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. He said, you know, our standing in the world and in the US "comes because of the vibrancy of American democracy." So, any business depends on that strong institution.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. He said, you know, our standing in the world and in the U S comes because of the vibrancy of American democracy. So, any business depends on that strong institution.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As an American company and tech company our standing in the world, and in the United States, comes because of the vibrancy of the American democracy, Nadella told Andrea Jung, the CEO of Grameen America, who hosted the talk. So therefore any standing of any business, including ours, depends on us building on that strong institution of democracy here and everywhere else.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Which is, uh, pretty profound coming from a business leader, especially with everything we're seeing politically.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, uh, pretty profound coming from a business leader, especially with everything we're seeing politically.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It really ties into that bigger picture of corporate responsibility, beyond just the bottom line.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It really ties into that bigger picture of corporate responsibility, beyond just the bottom line.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's not just about profit, it's about the entire ecosystem companies operate within.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's not just about profit, it's about the entire ecosystem companies operate within.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right. And, uh, it'll be interesting to see how many others truly embrace that full vision.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. And, uh, it'll be interesting to see how many others truly embrace that full vision.
